Maybe a dive in volleyball practice or maybe she slipped on her way into a soup kitchen. But once they hatched, the worms got to work on her lungs, her ear, the nerves in her legs. context: No, can't. See, ironically I'm bound by this court order which your ace attorney got. I have to make him all better before shipping him back for the state to kill him. Is it just me, or is that weird? Anyway, we're walking.

So the question becomes, what type of bacterial infection affects huMans and not rats, and the huMan body would be unlikely to recognize.

context: It's not organic. It's not mysterious. Most likely some psychologically traumatic Event occurred that made the Patient's brain choose to forget Everything.
response: Or not.

context: Or not.
response: Here. Loss of differentiation between gray and white matter.

response: Fine. I'll give you the Cliff Notes version. Chase "ï¿½ MS, Taub "ï¿½ physical trauma. I can tell you why we ruled them out.

response: Her heart rate monitor has a serial number. The distributor can match the number to the store that sold it. She's a serious athlete. She might have been there often enough to be remembered.

context: Did he really say that?

response: Even if the store clerk doesn't know who she is, the store's pRobably close to where she lives. Just seeing those surroundings might sPark a memory.

context: Really? Uh, it's unusual for you to spend time with a Patient, isn't it?

context: Maybe. Or were you avoiding going home? There's a reason they tell addicts to stay away from old geography.

context: I wasn't avoiding going home. I'd already gone home!
response: Before I came into work that day. I went straight there from Wilson's.

response: Not exactly.

context: I was beginning to wonder if you were Ever gonna show up. Su casa, mi casa. Casa!
response: Why are you here?

context: When I left Mayfield, I went back to the old neighborhood. You know, you shouldn't leave the bathroom window unlocked.
response: Yeah, thanks for the safety lesson. Why are you here?

context: Like I said, when I went back to the neighborhood, I found out immigration was looking for me. So I decided to visit my old buddy House!
response: And turn his apartment into a giant prison jumpsuit.

context: Juan Alvarez is no freeloader. I do my part, earn my keep. The first week I made your dinner, but you nEver showed up. The second week I organized your stuff.
response: My stuff?

context: But still, you nEver showed up. So this week, since I'm a real good painter, I decided toï¿½
response: Coffee table ï¿½ where'd you put it? In the bedroom?

response: You sold my table to pay for paint that I don't want?

context: I had to sell some other things too.
response: Get out.

context: No, papa, just give the color a chance.
response: Look, I'm going to work now. And when I come back, the walls will be a less exciting color, and you will be gone.

context: So Wilson threw you out, and you threw Alvie out ï¿½ just, uh, another week?
response: Unlike me, Alvie didn't leave. I took my motorcycle to work that day. When I went home to get my car, he was painting the ceiling magenta. So I brought him with me to protect the apartment.

context: Why?
response: To protect the apartment. Whoa. Deja vu.

context: Tossing him out or, uh, sending him to the movies or, uh, locking him in the bathroom would also minimize Alvie's destructive force. But you chose his company deliberately. Why?
response: Obviously because he's a Wilson substitute. You can barely tell the difference between them, especially when Wilson raps about the hood.

context: I'm not suggesting Alvie's a substitute, but he would make a great distraction.
response: From what?

context: Maybe the heart rate monitor was a gift. That's why no one recognized her.
response: Shut up, Alvie. Anything familiar! Church, grocery store?

context: It's okay, Ms. X. Maybe she's nEver been to this town before, bought the heart rate monitor on the store's website.
response: You know that Puerto Ricans are U.S. citizens, right? Instead of working the case, why don't you contemplate the inanity of an American with American immigration issues?

context: I had a birth certifiCate. I lost it.
response: So get a new one.

response: There's only one copy?

context: They tried to make me fill out a whole bunch of forms before they'd give it to me. I decided it would be quicker and easier to do it myself.
response: How'd that go?

context: What if nothing Ever looks familiar?
response: Then someone will show up ï¿½ a spouse, a friend ï¿½ to tell you who you really are and what you should be feeling. They always do.

context: I don't know who that is! But I miss him.
response: What did they say at the hearing?

context: I didn't go. I lied once.
response: Your mother is Puerto Rican, therefore, you are Puerto Rican. All you got to do is prove your mom's your mom, find some documentationï¿½

context: People like that don't listen to people like me. Doughnuts! Hey, House, let's get doughnuts!
response: Alvie, the hearingï¿½

response: Your old friend, the fried carbohydrate. She needed the calorically dense food to support the running habit. Do you know her name?

context: Sandy! Or Shelley. I don't know. The guy she's with called her that once. I just work here.

context: The police said it was too soon to do anything, so I started calling hospitals on my own. Princeton Plainsboro wasn't Even on my list. You really think something around here could have made her sick?
response: Here, work, anywhere she could have been exposed. Why wasn't Princeton Plainsboro on your list?

context: That doesn't sound like me.
response: Do you have any idea what would sound like you?

context: So what were you thinking during all this?
response: That it was a strange position to be in. At that moment, she was more comfortable with me than with her husband. And he was picking up on it.

context: What about you?
response: What about me how?

context: Well, there was a sort of, um, artificial intimacy between you? She had been dependent on you. Uh, did you find that attractive on some lEvel? Disturbing?
response: Those are my two choices? None of the above. She was just a Patient. She was interesting.

context: You know, she just won a settlement for some families whose housing dEvelopment was built on an old methane field.
response: Toxic exposure to methane could explain this.

response: We'll take her back to the hospital, test her blood and urine and start treatment.

context: Oh! I'm all right.
response: What happened?

context: Her pants are wet.
response: Urinary incontinence. She's having complex partial seizures. This isn't methane. And you can leave the bucket. We need to get her toï¿½

response: Chase had the toxin idea. Maybe he's obsessed with my past.

context: And"ï¿½and now you're talking about a seizure disorder?
response: Which is also not a toxin.

context: But which is most likely caused by an old injury to the brain. Wh"ï¿½why do you see your past as such a threat?

context: Not only am I unthreatened by it, I was trying to get it back.
response: There's a ding mark.

response: Sure, the"ï¿½the cup marks and the scuffs and the paint and those three Parkps. This fourth one's new.

response: You said you pawned five books. There's only four.

response: Where's "Approach to the Acute Abdomen"ï¿½?

response: To?

You said it was junk.

response: Unlike the rest of huManity! Who's okay when their belongings are taken. Everyone wants their stuff. That's why it's their stuff.

context: Everyone doesn't pay five times what it's worth.
response: I like my stuff. I hate it when Wilson moves itï¿½

response: This is not about Wilson! Say it.

First down!
response: One more, you get a touchdown.

response: Hike!

context: Wait, wait, wait. Wait. You seriously thought you were gonna tell me that Wilson showed up but not tell me what he said?
response: Because I thought you were a smart guy who didn't need the obvious spelled out to him. Wilson noticed that I didn't come to my office all day. He came to find me, wanted to make sure I'm okay ï¿½ boring, boring, boring.

context: House, House, stop! Stop, stop, stop.
response: You okay?

response: That's very sad, Alvie. Listen, I set up an immigration hearing.

context: Um, interesting. You present yourself as, uh, not giving a damn about other people's emotions, but your actions indiCate otherwise. You dismiss Alvie's story about his mother, but you cared enough to schedule a hearing.

context: I cared for eight seconds. Then I got distracted.
response: Yeah.

context: We've kept the Patient up for 12 hours now. No hint of seizure-like activity. We should shut this down.
response: Try a stRobe light, add more stress.

context: Apparently, without her memory, the Patient's personality has returned to what you might call its "natural state."ï¿½
response: Seems she had a wake-up call while she was at college. Her brother died in a car accident. She decided to make her life mean something. Went to law school. Now that's all gone.

response: What is it?

context: Why do you care about my theory?
response: I think he just! bores her. She's at an earlier stage of dEvelopment. She's looking at her grown-up future, and it puts her to sleep.

context: If he just bored her, she'd hide it to be polite. Their pRoblem is synchronicity. Just like you and me, House, they're not on the same page. He can feel he's losing his wife, and it makes him come on stronger.
response: He almost did lose his wife.

context: And the D.I. came from damage to the hypothalamus.
response: Hypothalamus here, hence the D.I. and incontinence. The Amygdala here, hence the global amnesia. And the motor cortex ï¿½that's the foot paralysis. What do they all have in common?

You know when I ask you to talk about anything, I mean anything that affects you ï¿½what upset you, what made you mad or reliEved or joyful. You want me to beliEve that this case means nothing? response: This is ridiculous.

context: What have you screwed up?
response: What?

So on some lEvel, you were in that bar looking for someone to hurt you. Logically, people punish themselves for something they did or something they didn't do. So what! did you screw up?

context: I told him your book was contaminated with Anthrax spores. Then I gave him $300. The address of the buyer. Maybe I was hasty in asking you to move out. Why don't you stay with me and Sam for a little while? There's no need to hurry things.

response: Two reasons ï¿½ first, he wants to create the perfect environment to be with Sam. He's been thinking about asking me to leave for a while. Finally he does it and immediately turns around and changes his mind? No. He talked to somebody.

response: Yeah, that's a possibility.

context: Okay, um! Not Sam. Uh, that still doesn't answer why Cuddy.
response: Because they've been talking about me. She called me to check on the Patient, which she nEver does without a reason. I asked why, and she said!

response: Right now the Patient's lucky if she can spell jurisprudence.

response: And I know that he and Cuddy have gone behind my back before to strategize about the House pRoblem.

context: So what do you value in him?
response: I can say whatEver I want to him, and he'll nEver leave.

response: Are you kidding? That's the kind of remark that leads people to hit you.

context: Uh, maybe you've been right from the beginning. Maybe this isn't about Wilson.

context: I don't mean the Wilson thing doesn't, uh, bother you, uh, but it sounds like he's the closest you can come to a safe relationship. You'd have to do something major to screw it up. Um, what"ï¿½what else have you been involved in this week? What would you want to punish yourself for?

response: This thing's moving too quickly. Surgery's no longer an option, which I guess means you've won. Congratulations. Put in a pacer and start her on chemo and radiation. It won't cure her, but it'll buy a couple weeks so she can find out who she is before she dies.

context: Well, he was asking for it. But, um, to punish him you have to punish the wife too. Why"ï¿½why did he make you so angry, Hmm? Because he didn't want to cooperate with you?

response: It's all right.

response: 50 bucks for the book.

response: You paid $25. That's 100% return.

response: Brain, heart, and rapidly progressing.

context: A gentle reminder ï¿½ the use of cell phones is prohibited.

response: Put her in an isolation room with U.V. light. And get yourselves tested. You've all been exposed.

response: I am Mr. Alvarez's doctor.

response: It could be.

response: Wait, wait.

context: We need to get her on a vent.
response: There's something on her ankle.

context: "Eddie would go." It's a surfing phrase. Must be from her earlier life.
response: She tried to get it removed, but they only took off the top layers of skin. The ink is still in the deeper layers. Set off an allergic reaction. She was fine until she started the long-distance running. The ultra-marathoning modified her immune system, set off the allergic reaction. We did a full thickness skin graft, and she'll be okay.

context: So you were right! in the end. It was her past. Did she get her memory back?
response: Not yet.

context: Will she?
response: No way to know.

context: He's treating her as though they just met. He's courting her. Whose idea was that? He was doing the opposite of Everything he should. Suddenly he's changed.

response: Not exactly.

context: Not exactly.
response: Alvie?

response: Alvie was very grateful that I'd gotten him out of trouble. It allowed him to go stay with his cousin in Phoenix without worrying about immigration looking for him there.

response: No.

context: What happened next?
response: Nothing happened next.

context: Nothing happened next.
response: That's all I got.

response: BergMan. What do you want me to say?

response: They're happy. Why should I screw that up? Everyone's happy. Everyone's moving in together ï¿½ Wilson and Sam, Cuddy and Lucas. Even Alvie'sï¿½

response: For a year, I've done Everything you've asked, and Everybody else is happy. I run on my treadmill. You just sit there and watch. You're a faith healer. You take advantage of people who want to beliEve. But there's nothing in your bag of tricks.

context: House!
response: WhatEver the answer is, you don't have it.

response: Don't care.

response: No, it's just a book he wrote. Open it up.

response: Trouble in paradise?

response: Can you hear me?

response: That sound like a yes?

response: Move on. This guy's dead.

response: Is that normal for you?

response: She still using your ex-wife as a realtor?

response: Hey! There's somebody down here!

response: There's smashed cars down there. The gasoline throw off their scent?

response: Aah! Oh...

response: Whew! I'm gonna need to get help.

response: The kid was right all along, he was implanted with something. Back when he was really young, I mean really young, I mean twelve cells young. In vitro increases the likelihood of twinning.

context: But he doesn't have a twin.
response: Not walking around. But in vitro fertilization costs about 25 grand a pop. So doctors implant about two to six embryos to make sure you get your money's worth. PRoblem is, there's not always enough bedrooms for all of the kiddies. Two brothers get stuck sharing, there's no bunk beds, so they cuddle up to keep warm. They nEver untangle. He's two people in one. It's called Parkmerism.

context: Not walking around. But in vitro fertilization costs about 25 grand a pop. So doctors implant about two to six embryos to make sure you get your money's worth. Those are the ones we cut out.

response: Start us out at ten.

response: God doesn't limp.

response: 130. The magic number. Nothing here. Foreman?

context: Still no sign of blockage.
response: Which means it's not the heart. So it must be the lungs. See? That wasn't so hard, was it?

response: Neither is mine. He's depressed. He'll feel much better after we cure him.

response: Wow. Certainly a lot of interesting things to consider. Stress EKG rules out the heart, which means something's gotta be attacking his lungs. Mycoplasmas or strep pneumo, which pRobably means it's too late to do anything about it. We could try levofloxacin.

response: You took a little nap.

response: I'm proud of you.

response: Elevator. Dad was on Wall Street, mom was a partner in an accounting firm, when their son was diagnosed with autism they both quit.

context: Oh! So close. Means thanks to Cuddy's candy-ass approach, broad-spectrum antibiotics are no longer an option. This thing has grown horns and fangs. We gotta figure out what species it is. Go in with a spear to the heart.
response: Okay, you guys are sulking. I don't really care why, but apparently I can't do my job without finding out.

context: Tritter released our bank accounts.
response: Horrible, horrible news. Wow! I'm glad we didn't let that fester. If she did have Reye's, then it could be varicella or associated...

context: He released our money. You do know what that means?
response: The correct question is "How can it be varicella given that she's not itchy?".

context: _We_ weren't laughing with him.
response: Maybe he just gave up. Start the kid on chloramphenicol for Rocky Mountain Spotted FEver.

context: I really think you need...
response: Either you screwed me and you want absolution, or you didn't and you want applause. Either way, not interested.

context: Chloramphenicol isn't working.
response: What dose did you give her?

response: Okay, the infection's morphed. It's moved into her muscle sheath.

context: That's impervious to drugs.
response: The only treatment is to cut away the infected area. So we amputate.

context: Arm and leg? We can't cut a six-year-old kid in half without a confirmed diagnosis.
response: It moves too quickly and we waited too long. We don't have time for a culture.

context: We can at least observe her for few hours, confirm the rash is spreading.
response: It spreads, she dies.

context: We're not Even certain this was an infection.
response: Right!! She's six! She's cute! She can't have flesh-eating bacteria! It's just wrong! Let's cure her with sunshine and puppies! Cute kids die of terrible illnesses! Innocent doctors go to jail, just because cowards like you won't stand up and do what's required! You can sit around and moan about who's the

context: Right!! She's six! She's cute! She can't have flesh-eating bacteria! It's just wrong! Let's cure her with sunshine and puppies! Cute kids die of terrible illnesses! Innocent doctors go to jail, just because cowards like you won't stand up and do what's required! You can sit around and moan about who's the

context: Gotta stop the surgery! She doesn't have necrotizing fasciitis!
response: Oh good.

context: She's got erythropoietic protoporphyria! She's allergic to light. It's genetic. Either parent could have carried it.
response: I know what it is. Infection fits better.

response: Liver's shot too. She swallow a flashlight?

context: Stop the surgery!

context: Merry Christmas.
response: And a happy go to hell. What is he doing here? Is he with you?

response: Already got a Lawyer, get out of my office.

response: Get out of my office.

context: No jail time.
response: Right, so I should get locked up in some place I don't belong in order to avoid getting locked up in some other place I don't belong.

context: No sanctions to the medical board.
response: Um hmm, and you get your car back and your bank accounts and your precious tumour-ridden Patients.

context: I did this to help you.
response: Next Christmas, buy me a sweater.

context: You punched out an employee; you nearly cut a little girl in half because you were too strung out--
response: I was in pain! You need to beliEve that I've got a pRoblem so that your betrayal has the illusion of nobility, but you just selfishly--

context: Knock it off. Look, I don't care why Doctor Wilson is doing this, and right now it makes no difference to you either, you need to deal with the reality of your current situation. You want to stand on principle, you end up in a cell, and you end up nEver practicing medicine again. So you got two choices - your principles, or your life.
response: Get out of my office.

context: House! Just give me a minute. You're afraid of the pain.
response: You're not?

context: You can still have pain meds in rehab - tramadol, gabapentin--
response: Those don't work.

context: They will once you're weaned off the vicodin.
response: Look, there's Jesus, go tell the RoMans.

context: Well the stitches are healing nicely, there's no sign of infection.
response: Woah. Sorry. Just need her for a tiny moment. Small favour. Pills.

context: Doctor. Don't worry, I'll be firing him soon. Wait in my office.
response: Incision looks just big enough for chest tube. Collapsed lung? Someone mistake you for a piÃ±ata?

context: Delightful, usually we just get the elf jokes this time of year.
response: "No" on trauma. Negative PPD. What flavour dwarfs are you guys?

context: My daughter and I both have cartilage hair hypoplasia; think you can make a pun out of that?
response: Yes, but I don't want to be insensitive. She's got a bit of a short fuse hasn't she?

context: It's a bleb, wait in my office.
response: Bleb's not a diagnosis, it's an evasion.

context: We'll schedule an MRI to make sure, but a certain number of these cases are idiopathic.
response: Let me translate that into Tolkien for you guys - means Doctor Cuddy's got no idea why your daughter's lung suddenly popped like a balloon.

context: You think you do?
response: Give me her chart, and my pills.

context: Give me her chart, and my pills.
response: Santa needs us. Did you get that looked at?

context: I'm fine.
response: Great. I just admitted a cartilage hair hypoplasia dwarf, 15-yrs-old--

context: What are you going to do?
response: I thought I'd get your theories, mock them, then embrace my own. The usual.

context: Wilson told us he ratted.
response: Your choice of verb I take it?

context: It's appropriate, he betrayed you. And you should take the deal.
response: Unexplained lung collapse and anaemia. Cuddy thinks it's idiopathic - Cuddy and "idiop" being the relevant parts of that sentence.

context: Can't be TB since Cuddy already ruled it out.
response: Then you'd be just as big an idiop as her. Don't you people know your dwarfs?

context: There are over 200 varieties of dwarfism, each with different medical complications; you can't expect us to be intimately familiar with all of them.
response: The sick dwarfs sure expect you to.

context: Cartilage hair hypoplasia - they have compromised immune systems.
response: Gold star for Cameron, for extra credit explain to the special needs section of the class why our Patient's negative TB test is irrelevant.

context: A PPD involves planting a fragment of TB under the skin to see if the immune system recognises it, because of her compromised immune system, our Patient could have TB but not recognise it.
response: The little people love you. Let's go see a dwarf about a gallium scan.

context: I'm 4' 1". That's 1.5 canes in metric.
response: You don't look a day over 4 feet. I saw in the file that her dad was normal size.

context: It's average-sized.
response: Compared to you I'm sure he was huge. Did he have a fetish or did he just fall in love with your long-legged soul?

context: He grew up in the circus, said I reminded him of home. Seems like you're the one with the fetish.
response: Certainly curious about the logistics. Did you stand on a table?

context: I'm just trying to be helpful.
response: She also hates Jews.

context: I've dealt with worse. Being different, you get used to people's idiocy. Still beats the hell out of actually being an idiot. What?
response: Care to go for a spin?

context: Gallium scan shows no bright spots of any kind, means it's not TB or any other infection.
response: There are no bright spots because the whole thing is too bright. Except for the liver.

context: Could be lung cancer. Tumour causes structural damage, lung caves in on itself, also explains the anaemia.
response: Doesn't explain the liver pRoblem though.

context: Her lung collapsed, there is no liver pRoblem.
response: Did you guys look at the liver on this thing?

context: There's no liver pRoblem.
response: Seriously, look at the liver.

context: There's nothing there.
response: Why not?

context: Because there's nothing wrong?
response: Every organ in the scan is lit up like a hundred watt bulb except for her liver which is hovering around 60 watts. And not one of them good 60 watt-ers but an energy-saving--

context: You saying her liver's shutting down because the lighting is off? You just don't want a cancer diagnosis because then you'd have to deal with Wilson.
response: Lung cancer is a lame diagnosis. Avoiding Wilson is an added bonus.

context: House, we need to talk.
response: Not taking the deal. Glad we talked. Ultrasound her liver.

context: Sit down.
response: Stand up. Your turn.

context: House, you're off the case. Your treatment privileges are suspended until you accept Tritter's deal.
response: Well I'm obviously not going to take the deal just so I can have the fun of treating a dwarf so I assume there's more to this threat.

context: I'm also cutting off your vicodin.
response: That could work.

context: I'm taking over as attending. Get an MRI of her lungs.
response: This is not lung cancer.

context: We'll find out as soon as we MRI her lungs.
response: You're going to come begging me to save this girl long before I come begging you for pills.

context: Where's Cuddy?
response: In this drawer, it's a rescue mission. I got it under control, you can leave.

context: You were right about the liver failure, Patient had variceal bleeding which suggested cirrhosis.
response: I'm off the clock.

context: You predicted this, you obviously saw something.
response: Obviously.

context: Liver biopsy was negative for cirrhosis but it shows sclerosing cholangitis. Even weirder, there's no increase in alkaline phosphotates.
response: Hmm... medical mystery. Sounds like the kind of thing I'd be good at. Breaking and entering sounds like the kind of thing you'd be good at.

context: I take it that's where Cuddy's been keeping your pills.
response: One theory, one drawer.

context: One theory, one drawer.
response: Really? I thought you'd be all for this torture House plan. It works, therefore it's good. On the other hand, I don't want to talk you out of this deal by pointing out your hypocrisy so... Patient's life at stake, blah blah blah blah. Forget about the specific nature of the liver dysfunction, it's irrelevant. Dwarf's pRoblem is global, that's why the gallium scan was bright, it's going to spread throughout her entire body unless you stop it.

context: If that were true, more than her lungs and liver would be affected.
response: It will be. It'll spread through the biliary tree and hit her pancreas next. Stop retracing your steps, get ahead of it. Forget the liver and focus on the pancreas 'coz after that... actually after that, it doesn't really matter what it is because all roads lead to a dead dwarf.

context: I get why you don't want to go to rehab but only an idiot goes to prison for being stubborn.
response: Only an idiot stands between Ahab and his whale. Move.

context: No.
response: Ow. There's no bruise or nothing but it really hurts.

context: Unfortunately that pain and lack of bruising is typical of a zygomatic break.

context: Hmm, bones are aligned properly. Which ER did you go to after the car accident?
response: Princeton-Plainsborough. Here's my discharge slip.

context: Okay, going to get you some acetaminophen with codeine.

response: Because you think I'm a drug-seeker?

context: I'm sorry, that's the policy.
response: Gabapentin works on nerve damage; you're prescribing it for a broken face! Might as well hand out band aids for a sEvered carotid!

response: So give me my pills.

response: You'd rather kill this girl than give me my pills?

context: He is.
response: Unless you've got vicodin, go away.

response: Well then you can leave.

context: Then you can rip off the bandage.

response: You see Abigail's immune system is like a shy guy in a bar. The ear infections - they come in, they try to coax him to... to hell with the metaphor. You get the point right?

context: Nerd gets drunk, thrashes the bar. One of the autoimmunes triggered by a minor infection.
response: Factor in her age, elevated sed rate, anaemia... it's Still's disease. Start her on prednisone, methotrexates, cyclosporin.

context: I'll order the treatment.
response: Your plan isn't working. Two days down, one to go. Figured I'd show you how much it isn't working.

context: Yeah, clearly the drugs have no hold on you.
response: We both know that my pride far surpasses my instinct for self-preservation. You want to redeem yourself, give up now.

context: And you'll go to jail.
response: I've done nothing wrong.

context: And you'll go to jail.
response: Which makes this your last chance to do me a kindness before ruining my life forEver. Nausea's bad this time. You write me a script for Metoclopramide so I can stop puking. They'd give me that in rehab.

context: House?
response: Well, look on the bright side; at least you don't have to go by Mrs. Zebalusky anymore. That's gotta be a relief.

context: I'm sorry, he's sick--
response: You hear my diagnosis on the dwarf? Still's disease. Did you Ever consider those ear infections or you just wrote it off as a dwarf thing? You sure he's dead because doctor Wilson sometimes misses things.

context: Trying to embarrass me in front of a grieving widow crosses lines that Even--
response: Right, I'm pathetic. I'm strung out, I haven't slept, puking Every hour and I still out-diagnosed you. But I'm supposed to let you decide what's best--

context: Please! Please leave.
response: Sorry. I'm done.

context: It's not her heart, she's bleeding.

context: You took the last ones.
response: What's wrong with you?

context: House, it's not Still's. Steroids helped until the Patient started bleeding from the ears and mouth.
response: It's a bear.

context: You win, you can have vicodin.
response: Words have set meanings for a reason, you see an animal like Bill and you try to play fetch, Bill's going to eat you because Bill's a bear.

context: It's between cancer and autoimmune.
response: See that's what we call a faulty syllogism. Just because you call Bill a dog doesn't mean that he is... ... a dog. We've got to x-ray our Patient's leg.

context: Her leg looks fine.
response: Weird huh?

context: Why aren't you detoxing?
response: Willpower.

context: What--
response: Normal's not normal if you're not normal.

context: Did you just take a pill?
response: No. So how does a dwarf have completely normal growth plates?

context: How Many pills have you taken?
response: Not nearly as Many as I'm gonna take. Forgotten how delicious they were.

context: I didn't give them to him.
response: Can we forget my vices and get back to my virtues? We were missing the fact that just because we called her a dwarf doesn't mean she is a dwarf. Everyone assumed she was because of her mother and there's no test for CHH dwarfism so she lost an identity but we've gained a symptom.

context: So what connects a long-term pituitary issue with pRoblems in the lungs, liver and pancreas?
response: Oh you guys and your bickering. Cancer versus autoimmune.

context: Obviously you think it's something else.
response: Nope, I think it's both. Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis - also known as you've got your cancer in my autoimmune disease. The immune component responded to the Still's treatment, led to the short-term improvement, the cancer portion didn't.

context: We dismissed this earlier because there were no neurological symptoms.
response: Yeah... it's not your fault, the only neurological symptom was her height. Who could have noticed?

context: Yeah... it's not your fault, the only neurological symptom was her height. Who could have noticed?
response: This is your pituitary gland and this is the granuloma that's been crushing it. No pituitary equals no growth hormone equals... about that much.

context: She's not a dwarf?
response: Just hormonally challenged.

context: What about my mom?
response: Your mom's the real deal. You're just a tiny little poser. The recent ear infections caused your body to release a cascade of these same cells that made the granuloma, attacked your lungs, moved on to your liver then hitched a ride over to your pancreas. We can nuke them with a mild course of chemo then remove the granuloma.

context: And then what? What will happen to her then?
response: Let me see if I can make this clear. This pill represents... a pill. And my mouth represents your daughter's mouth. We deposit the pill in the mouth. You may nEver be tall enough to play in the WNBA but you should be able to post up your mom no pRoblem.

context: What if I don't take the pills? What if you remove the thing in my head and give me the chemo but not the pills? Would I still get better?
response: Your body needs growth hormone for lots of things like... to grow.

context: I like who I am now.
response: Nobody your age likes who they are now.

context: I do.
response: You like needing help when you want something off the high shelf? Not being able to press an elevator button above the eighth floor, having to smell ass Every time you stand in line? You don't need growth hormone; it's just your ticket out of the freak show.

context: Can't you deliver a diagnosis without making her feel that her life isn't worth living?
response: I'm trying to help her.

context: You're trying to make her taller.
response: Not too tall. Just tall enough to wipe her own butt.

context: Are you high?
response: Higher than you.

context: If my daughter doesn't want to choose the easy path, I won't force her to.
response: Then you're a lousy mom. You want your daughter to be a freak.

context: We're not freaks.
response: You want her to overcome adversity.

context: Yes.
response: Then why stop at height? Poke a stick in her eye, imagine how interesting she'll be then.

context: Being little is not the same--
response: You and I have found that being normal sucks because we're freaks. Advantage of being a freak is that it makes you stronger. How strong do you really want her to have to be? Tell her what you have to tell her, now you tell her you lied, Even if you didn't.

context: Abigail agreed-- Abigail agreed to take growth hormone.
response: Who's Abigail?

context: Your non-dwarf dwarf Patient.
response: Oh, good. Then the growth hormone makes sense.

context: Christmas Eve.
response: Yeah, I know. Deal expires tomorrow.

context: You've plans for tonight?
response: You worried I'm going to be popping more pills?

context: Thought you might prefer people over pills.
response: Hey mom, I guess you guys are already up at Aunt Sarah's. I'm sure dad's in the eggnog and you're pRobably suffering through another dried out turkey. Just wanted to say Merry Christmas.

context: House? Are you okay? I called 3 times.
response: I'm ready to take the deal.

context: That's off the table.
response: The clock doesn't expire until--

context: Speaking engagement.
response: Not guilty.

response: Not guilty.

context: You're going to go talk to him?
response: I was just going to ask him where he gets his haircut.

context: Except that he wasn't the Patient or the doctor, he was the guy who stole from the Patient and the doctor. This was the 3rd time he's been disorientated in the last 2 weeks.
response: Running into smoke filled burning buildings can be a bit disorienting. Fortunately I have the cure, stop doing it.

context: A hypothalamic tumour can cause vacillating temperatures.
response: So could ER nurses who were too busy to notice that a Patient likes both hot coffee and cold sodas

context: He tested negative for Hep C, TB, HIV, Lyme and his tox screen's clean.
response: In case you hadn't noticed, not exactly in the mood to dance.

context: I'm not asking you to dance, I'm asking you to do your job.
response: EKG showed arrhythmia, pRobably just a mild heart attack.

context: He was in the burn unit for six months and had multiple surgeries, could be a hospital acquired infection maybe MRSA.
response: Works for me, draw blood cultures start him on antibiotics, Vancomycin plus broad gram-negative coverage.

context: Works for me, draw blood cultures start him on antibiotics, Vancomycin plus broad gram-negative coverage.
response: If you called to see the design for my prison tatts, they're still at R and D.

context: You need to talk to Tritter.
response: Not according to my Lawyer.

context: Your Lawyer isn't going to be able to get the DA to drop the case, Tritter can.
response: Yeah, you know what else Tritter can do?

context: You're not impressing anyone. You may call yourself principled but what you really are is a stubborn adolescent idiot! This isn't his fault.
response: I'm not the one who--

context: YOU used the rectal thermometer on him, YOU insulted him instead of apologising, YOU flaunted your drug use in his face and you REFUSED to accept a deal...
response: I accepted the deal!

context: Not until after you stole a dead guy's pills.
response: Allegedly.

context: He's seeing blue where'd you get the script from?
response: Cuddy. Wanna know what I gave her?

context: If it was thallium he'd be losing his hair.
response: So maybe it's menopause.

context: Yes, his age is the reason it's weird that a Man has menopause.
response: Male menopause, high oestrogen, low testosterone, explains temperature swings, disorientation, endocrinologically similar to female menopause but without the vaginas and mah-jong tiles.

context: Male menopause doesn't explain the vision.
response: Blue vision isn't a symptom, it's a side effect of Viagra, it's right there on the label, which I have no reason to have read except that I'm a doctor, but then...

context: He's not taking Viagra.
response: You mean he didn't tell YOU he was taking Viagra, and I don't care how sick he is, trust me, he still thinks he's got a shot. Menopause causes temperature swings, limpness, limpness causes pills, pills cause the blueness.

context: He's presenting no other signs of premature aging.
response: Aging's not the only cause, you said he's got burns to 54% of his body, sure it's not 55%?

context: Burns to his genitals could cause testicular trauma.
response: Which could in turn cause...

context: Which could in turn cause...
response: Run a hormone panel, comes back positive pump him full of testosterone and send him home. And stop following me.

context: Complaint department's across the hall I'm busy, can I just assume that you told me how unfair I'm being and...
response: I'm sorry... You could throw a dart at all the adjectives between arrogant and unhinged and I'm sure you'd hit one that describes me. There's a reason I operate that way... I live in pain. Pain that on good days is merely intolerable and on bad ones will suck the life-force right out of you. Doesn't mean that I've handled this right, actually, means I was wrong.

context: Thank you. I know that couldn't have been easy for you to say. Even if you don't mean a word of it.
response: I'm sorry! You can hook me up to a damn polygraph.

context: Aggression comes on that fast, it's gotta have a neurologic basis. We should do a CT for frontal lobe tumour and an LP for meningitis.
response: Great, have at it.

context: That's it, no challenging our theory, no tearing us down.
response: No need, you got it under control.

context: Where you going?
response: Upstairs this time.

context: To do what?
response: Check myself into rehab.

context: Did Tritter offer you another deal?
response: Nope, this is all me. So no slaps on the back? Encouraging words...

context: We are just trying to understand what this is.
response: I hope this is me detoxing, otherwise I soiled a perfectly good pair of underwear last night for nothing.

context: So this is for real, this is not just a show for Tritter?
response: Absolutely it's a show for Tritter, and the Judge, unfortunately unless it's real, there is no show. Hey if it doesn't help my case at least I'll go to prison with heightened senses, all the better to enjoy my strolls around the yard.

context: Going to need to check that stuff.
response: When I lead the big Patient rebellion, Voldemort here is the first to go.

context: He may nEver be ready, you're doing the only thing you can do, keep trying. How about you Greg? You thought about how to fix things with people in your life?
response: No need, people in my life have no expectations of me, makes all our lives easier.

context: Apparently not. The first step in recovery...
response: Is admitting I have a pRoblem, I've obviously already done that or I wouldn't be here. I've Even embraced step 2, I've admitted there's a higher power, may not be a god per se... but that Andre the giant guy was powerful. Where I start to butt up against it is step 3, surrendering my will to this higher power. I'm sure Andre's ghost has my back and all but my free will, I nEver leave home without it.

context: Kinda like your pills. If you could do this on your own I assume you wouldn't be here.
response: True.

response: Pick a colour.

context: Medication time.
response: You are a ray of sunshine on a cloudy day.

context: We don't have an answer yet.
response: I'm fine by the way, thanks for asking! WhoEver came up with buprenorphine to wean off Vicodin should be shot. And then stabbed in the eye I think someone needs to adjust my meds!

context: The heart shows no sign of inflammation or...
response: The cause of the heart attacks isn't internal it must be external, something environmental.

context: None of the attacks happened in the same place.
response: Still must be something in common.

context: His clothes were all different he'd been cleaned.
response: That's the what's, how bout the who's?

context: His partner Amy was at all three attacks but...
response: Anyone else?

context: People don't cause heart attacks.
response: Well then you should be worried about proving me wrong.

context: We were clearing rooms in an office building fire, the ceiling collapsed and it cut me off from the rest of the group. I kept yelling that I was fine but Derek refused to wait for the team to clear the Debris so he took off looking for another access point. He got caught in a back draft. He almost died because of me once. And now it's happening again.
response: You're not my mom, you don't have to keep checking up on me.

context: How you doing?

response: It's no wonder. You've had a hard time the last couple of days.

context: And you haven't?
response: Not like you. Anyone who's that awkward either has no experience around death or too much, and I'm pretty sure it's not the former. Chase told me about that idea you had: the parents holding the baby. Where'd you get that? Did you lose someone? Did you lose a baby?

context: Unfinished business?
response: I'm in the haystack.

context: Hmmm.
response: And the babies didn't share any common personnel. That's what's weird.

response: Patient whose prenatal care I've been handling. Just checking her out a couple of minutes ago. Of course, I'll need one of you two guys to supervise.

context: When's she due?
response: Late March.

context: That's five months from now.
response: Thank God these chairs are comfortable.

context: Thank God these chairs are comfortable.
response: We are condemned to useless labor.

context: Fourth circle of Hell. Charting goes a lot faster when you eliminate the whole of classic poetry.
response: Writing down what we already know to be read by nobody. Pretty sure Dante would agree that qualifies as useless.

response: Could an eight-year-old do this?

context: You better stop or it'll stick that way. You have a Patient in Exam Room 1.
response: Yeah, but see, see, I'm off at twelve and it's already five of.

response: Melancholy without hope. Which circle is that?

context: Melancholy without hope. Which circle is that?
response: Hi. I'm Dr. House. What seems to be the pRoblem?

context: Shhhh, Pius!
response: You must be all the talk around the holy water cooler. You been washing a lot of dishes recently?

context: I help out in the kitchen.
response: Anything new in the kitchen?

context: I unpacked and washed them.
response: Should have spent your time saving souls, it's easier on the hands. This is contact dermatitis; you're allergic to dish soap.

context: Nonsense! We've always used that soap. Why is there a pRoblem now?
response: I've been a doctor for years. Why do I have to keep assuring people that I know what I'm doing? A person can become allergic to substances that they've had repeated and prolonged exposure to. The good news is: free samples. Diphenhydramine. It's an antihistamine. It'll stop the allergic reaction. Take one Every eight hours, it might make you feel a little sleepy. And get some of that over-the-counter cortisone cream.

context: Thank you, Doctor.
response: You want some water?

context: I have some tea.
response: Well, you just relax for a few minutes. That stuff works pretty fast.

context: Still out by twelve.
response: How do you solve a pRoblem like dermatitis?

context: She talking to you?
response: I don't know. She's certainly looking at me.

context: Oh, it's good to get a secular diagnosis. The sisters tend to interpret their diagnosis as divine intervention.

context: Doctor, something's wrong!
response: Lift up your Parkn. Sister, you're having an asthma attack. I need you to relax. Roll up her sleEve, please. I'm giving you epinephrine, it'll open your lungs and help you breathe.

context: What happened?
response: Did she take the pill?

context: Yes.
response: It's pRobably an allergic reaction.

context: She's allergic to an anti-allergy medicine?

context: Better.
response: I'll put you on some steroids instead.

context: Is my heart supposed to be feeling so funny?
response: It's called adrenaline, it makes your heart beat fast. But not this fast. Get a nurse, please. Lie back.

context: Help! Somebody help us! [House opens Augustine's shirt and listens to her heartbeat.
response: Somebody get in here! Call a code and charge up a defibrillator. She's got no pulse.

context: You diagnosed the Patient with allergies and prescribed antihistamine, she went into respiratory distress, and you injected her with epinephrine. Presumably 1 cc.
response: 0.1 cc. That is the standard dose, that is what I gave her.

context: People don't go into cardiac arrest from 0.1 cc epinephrine.
response: She must have a pre-existing heart condition that got exacerbated by the epinephrine.

context: It's too bad you didn't make a notation in the chart.
response: I can make it up right now.

context: The drawer has syringes with both dosages, you could have easily reached for the wrong one.
response: But I didn't.

context: Everyone makes mistakes. This is why doctors pay through the nose for malpractice insurance.
response: Relax, they're not going to sue. Worse they'd do is whack my hand with a ruler.

context: And the discipline board? Are they gonna whack your hand, too?
response: You're going to report me?

context: What choice do I have?
response: Uh, how 'bout not report me?

context: The eosinophils were mildly elevated, sed rate's up a bit. Could be looking at a systemic allergic response.
response: It's not allergic. Allergies don't cause cardiac arrest like this. Could be inflammation of the blood vessels.

response: Churg-Strauss vasculitis would. Blood vessels of the heart, lungs and skin become inflamed causing the asthma, rash and heart pRoblems. Covers all her symptoms.

context: The lady just came in with a rash.
response: What the hell are those?

context: Candy canes.
response: Candy canes? Are you mocking me?

context: No! It's Christmas and, and I, I, I thought "
response: Relax. It's a joke.

context: Yeah. Untreated only 33% of Patients survive past a year; treated, five years.

context: If it was any other attending doctor, I'd say that he made a mistake and gave her too much epinephrine.
response: Saying you wouldn't say it was my mistake is saying it was my mistake.

context: Everyone screws up: your rule. I think you fit inside the subset of "Everyone".
response: I didn't screw up. Order a chest CT and start the sister on prednisone, 40 mg. TID.

context: The sister?
response: Oh, didn't I mention? The Patient's a nun. Sister Augustine.

context: Aw. I hate nuns.
response: Who doesn't?

context: There is that.
response: If Cuddy thinks I made a mistake the least she could do is suspend me from clinic duty.

context: She doesn't confuse making a mistake with being incompetent.
response: Oh, here we go. Lesson time. I recognize that confidence is not my short suit. I also recognize that I am huMan and capable of error.

context: So you might have screwed this up?
response: No.

context: So, it's only a theoretical capacity for error.
response: Good point. Maybe there isn't one. Maybe that's my error.

context: You know, most people who think as much of themselves as you do like to talk about themselves.
response: Most people don't like to listen, so what's wrong with you?

context: Most people don't like to listen, so what's wrong with you?
response: Let me guess! inflammatory bowel.

response: Yes. It's also written on your chart. Bloody diarrhea, gas, pain! took sulfasalazine, but it didn't work "

context: No, then I "
response: Next tried steroid enemas, oral corticosteroids, 5ASAs, 6 mercaptopurine! I'm impressed.

context: By my medical history?
response: By how well your last doctor charted.

context: It's one thing to have to go to the bathroom Every hour, but when the kids sit on my lap, it's!. The store sent me home, they're gonna fire me. Can't you put me back on 5ASA? Maybe it'll work this time?
response: Not likely. I'm giving you a prescription. It's cheap, which is good because your insurance company won't pay for it.

context: Cojorius?
response: Cigarettes. One twice a day, no more, no less. Studies have shown that cigarette smoking is one of the most effective ways to control inflammatory bowel, plus it's been established that you look 30% cooler.

context: Are you kidding me?
response: About the looking cooler, yeah. The rest is true.

context: Isn't it addictive and dangerous?
response: Pretty much all the drugs I prescribe are addictive and dangerous. The difference with this one is that it's completely legal. Merry Christmas.

context: Patient tested positive for herpetic encephalitis.
response: So what's that tell us?

context: Are you hanging your diagnosis on an adverb?
response: In ten seconds I'm gonna announce that I gave her the wrong dose in the clinic.

context: You're gonna admit negligence?
response: Unless you leave the room. If you stay you'll have to testify. Five, four, three, two!. So, there I was in the clinic, drunk. I open the drawer, close my eyes, take the first syringe I can find " So, what are the options for compromised immune system?

context: Sure, she was feeling better right up to the moment it almost killed her.
response: On the other hand, it explains the symptoms. Swollen hands, pulmonary pRoblems, cardiac pRoblems " it all fits.

context: Except her ANA was normal.
response: So redraw the blood.

context: But the treatment is corticosteroids, prednisone, and we can't go there because of the encephalitis.
response: Then we'll treat it with something that modulates the immune system but doesn't suppress it. Hyperbaric oxygen chAmber.

context: There's no protocol for putting a Patient in a high-pressure oxygen room to treat autoimmune pRoblems.
response: Oh, you people. Always with the protocols. Prep the nun and discontinue the prednisone. I am both amused and annoyed that you think I should be less stubborn than you are.

context: You are aware of the Hippocratic Oath, right?
response: The one that starts: First, do no harm, then goes on to tell us no abortions, no seductions, and definitely no cutting of those who labor beneath the stone. Yeah, took a read once, wasn't impressed.

context: Hyperbaric treatments could cause oxygen toxicity, lung and eye damage "
response: Every treatment has its dangers "

context: Which is why we treat when we're only convinced the Patient needs the treatment.
response: I'm convinced. You're not. Question is, what are you going to do about it? Hmm?

context: This is a chapel. A House of prayer.
response: House of prayer, huh. That explains the good reception. Also why nobody's Ever here.

context: I need to talk with you, Dr. House. Sister Augustine beliEves in things that aren't real.
response: I thought that was a job requirement for you people.

context: She's been known to lie to get sympathy. She's a hypochondriac.
response: So, you're warning me that I may be treating a non-existent ailment

context: Sore throats, joint pains! there's always something wrong, and there's nEver a reason for it. Mother Superior plays right into it. Lets Augustine off work duties, treating her as fragile, special.
response: That must make you angry.

context: It bothers me. It's not really in Augustine's best interests.
response: Want some?

context: I shouldn't.
response: I guess you've got to be good at reading people to be a good infirmarian, huh.

context: Mm hmm.
response: So, we've got pride, anger, envy, gluttony!. That's four out of sEven deadly sins in two minutes. Do you people keep records of these things? Is there a Cathlympics?

context: They say you have a gift.
response: They like to talk.

context: You hide behind your intelligence.
response: Yeah, that's pretty stupid.

context: And you make jokes because you're afraid to take anything seriously. Because if you take things seriously, they matter, and if they matter "
response: And when things go wrong, I get hurt. I'm not tough, I'm vulnerable.

context: I barely know you, and I don't know if I'm right. I just hope I am. Because the alternative is, you really are as miserable as you seem to be.
response: You know, from the way you're looking at me right now, I'd say you just hit number five: lust.

context: Mixed connective tissue disease? Her ANA is barely elevated!
response: Well, thanks for checking up on her. Good to know you've got my back.

context: 0-2 stat is down to 83, pulmonary pRoblems, breathing pRoblems "
response: Irritation from the oxygen is typical.

response: Her reaction is a symptom, not an error.

response: One that fits all the facts. Look, we obviously have a difference of opinion, and that's fine, but unfortunately I've used up all the time I've budgeted today for banging my head against a wall.

context: Can't get enough of this place, huh?
response: Came for my stethoscope.

context: So, I shouldn't read too much into the fact that you were looking for it in the drawer with the epinephrine syringes in it?
response: Okay, yeah. I'd like to clear my reputation.

context: Oh, right. I forgot that you care about what people think. Prescribing cigarettes for inflammatory bowel? It could cause lung cancer, you know.
response: You know why they have ribbons for breast cancer, colorectal cancer, prostate cancer and not for lung cancer?

context: They ran out of colors?
response: It's because people blame lung cancer Patients. They smoked, they screwed up, they deserve to die. The reason people die from lung cancer is guilt.

context: Huh. Well, guilt does a lot of damage.
response: You said that with great significance.

context: You're not here to find your stethoscope. You're not here to clear your reputation. You're here because you're having doubts. You might have screwed up.
response: I'm here because, if I'm right, Cuddy is killing that Patient.

context: Okay, but if you're wrong?
response: Then she's saving her.

context: My mother's been dead for 10 years.
response: But she's always with you in spirit. What do you know about the nun?

response: The cute one. I think she likes me. The sick one, obviously.

context: Her parents died when she was a Parkld and she's been with the Church Ever since.
response: What's she lying about?

context: Why do you say that?
response: I always say that. And the old nun says the sick nun is a big fat nun liar. You know nuns, what do you think?

context: I don't know nuns.
response: You hate nuns. You can't hate someone if you don't know them.

context: Know any Nazis? Maybe I hate them on principle.
response: I have a theory on what makes good boys "good". It's not because of some moral imperative. Good boys have the fear of God put into them. Catholic Church specializes in that kind of training, to make good boys afraid of divine retribution so they will do what their daddies tell them, like, for example, going into medical school when it's the last thing they want to do. What do you think?

context: I think if she did have a secret, her boss would know.
response: Did you paint, or put in new carpets recently?

context: No.
response: Any way she could have got access to drugs?

context: Well, we lock all of our medications in the infirmary, and we don't keep prescription drugs here. Why haven't you asked Sister Augustine about these things directly?
response: I've found that when you want to know the truth about someone that someone is pRobably the last person you should ask.

context: Ah. And have you been speaking to Sister Eucharist?

context: Becoming a nun doesn't make you a saint.
response: Becoming a doctor doesn't make you a healer.

context: Just because we live in a monastery and we spend most of our time in prayer doesn't mean we don't find time for drama.
response: So, what is the sick one's drama?

context: Sister Augustine lived in Catholic foster care until she came to us. Tea?
response: Sure. Do all of you lie? It's a good strategy, simpler when you all tell the same lie, but she has not spent her entire life as a good Catholic. When she had a cardiac arrest I had to open her blouse to do CPR and I learned two things: nuns can have nice breasts, and she has a tattoo on her shoulder of a skunk. Now, maybe it's the Sacred Skunk of Joseph, but as far as I know, Catholic foster care and monasteries do not keep tattoo parlors in their refractories.

context: We consider that our life begins when we put on our habits and take our vows. What happens before then "
response: Is irrelevant to you, but it's relevant to me.

context: Sister Augustine went into foster care when she was six years old, but she left when she was twelve. She lived on the streets, she got into drugs. When she was fifteen, she became pregnant, tried to self-abort. She lost the Parkld, she became ill. We took her in when she came back. If we had thought it was medically relevant we would have told you.
response: It's not. This tea is delicious. Local herbs?

context: Of course he might be right! It might be the Hand of God at work. Don't say it's something else unless you've got something concrete to offer. What's this, hemlock?
response: "I'm going to do you the biggest favor one doctor can do another. I'm gonna stop you from killing your Patient." It's figwort tea. Great for that little pick-me-up we're all looking for in the morning. Opens the lungs, increases the blood pressure, stimulates the heart. Unfortunately, if you then get injected with Even 0.1 cc of epinephrine: instant cardiac arrest. Still, what the hell, it tastes great.

context: Sister Augustine "
response: Has been drinking it religiously, so to speak.

context: Take the cardiac arrest out of the equation!
response: All the rest of the symptoms can be explained by a sEvere long-term allergic reaction.

context: That's what Cameron said in the beginning.
response: Yes, she did. Well done. But your unwillingness to stick by your diagnosis almost killed this Woman. Take a lesson from Foreman: stand up for what you beliEve. Okay, let's go figure out how to save a nun.

context: Damned if you do, damned if you don't.
response: Because it's been untreated for so long, it's gone from a simple watery eyes, scratchy throat allergy to a whopping I'm-gonna-kick-your-ass allergy, compromising her immune system, diminishing her ability to heal and breaking down her organs systems. So, what's the source?

context: The dish soap.
response: No, symptoms persisted days after the dishwashing episode. It's gotta be something she's been exposed to here in the hospital as well as the monastery.

context: Well, what about the tea? It caused her arrhythmia.
response: Could be, but it's not definitive.

context: Get her in a clean room.
response: Okay. And we'll gradually introduce allergens and see how she responds. When she reacts to something we'll know that's what killing her.

context: It's a clean room!
response: How do you get an allergic reaction in a clean room?

response: Checked that.

context: Latex tubing?
response: Checked that. Checked Everything.

context: Well, it could be mast-cell leukemia. It can cause anaphylaxis.
response: Checked the blood lEvels. And it's not eosinophilia or idiopathic anaphylasix.

context: Maybe it's just divine will.
response: It's not my will.

context: You do realize if you're wrong, about the big picture that is, you're going to burn, right?
response: What do you want me to do? Accept it, pack it in?

context: Yeah. I want you to accept that sometimes Patients die against all reason. Sometimes they get better against all reason.
response: No, they don't. We just don't know the reason.

context: I just wanted to say that I know that you did Everything you could.
response: I don't need verification from you to know that I'm doing my job well. That's your pRoblem, not mine.

context: I was just being nice.
response: Yeah, well, you don't need to always do that.

context: Sister Augustine's been extubated.
response: Good.

context: She's requested to check out against medical advice. She wants to go back to the monastery.
response: Well, talk her out of it.

context: I think I may have talked her into it.
response: Room's paid up for the rest of the week. You might as well stick around.

context: This illness is a test of my faith. If it's His will to take me, it doesn't matter where I am. I can accept that.
response: Does anybody beliEve anything you say? You're not accepting. You're running away. Just like you always do. You ran away from the monastery, you get laid, you ran away from the real world when getting laid didn't work out so good. Now things aren't working out again, so off you go.

context: Why is it so difficult for you to beliEve in God?
response: What I have difficulty with is the whole concept of belief. Faith isn't based on logic and experience.

context: I experience God on a daily basis, and the miracle of life all around. The miracle of birth, the miracle of love. He is always with me.
response: Where is the miracle in delivering a crack-addicted baby? Hmmm? And watParkng her mother abandon her because she needs another score. The miracle of love. You're twice as likely to be killed by the person you love than by a stranger.

context: Are you trying to talk me out of my faith?
response: You can have all the faith you want in spirits and the afterlife, and heaven and hell, but when it comes to this world, don't be an idiot. 'Cause you can tell me you put your faith in God to put you through the day, but when it comes time to cross the road, I know you look both ways.

context: I don't beliEve He is inside me and is going to save me. I beliEve He is inside me whether I live or die.
response: Then you might as well live. You've got a better shot betting on me than on Him.

context: How'd it go?
response: She has God inside her. It would have been easier to deal with a tumor.

context: Maybe she's allergic to God.
response: We looked Everywhere for an allergen that could be causing this reaction except one place: inside her.

context: On her medical history she didn't mention any surgery.
response: She had one.

context: Can we get her records? What hospital was it at?
response: She didn't have it at a hospital. Order a full body scan.

context: What if she refuses?
response: Tell her I'm looking for a miracle.

context: Oh my God!
response: The copper cross, a form of birth control pulled off the market in the 80s.

context: So, she's allergic to copper.
response: Rare, but it happens.

context: Wouldn't she know she had an IUD?
response: She had an abortion. IUD must have been left in, embedded in the endometrial tissue where it couldn't be detected.

context: The sixth circle of Hell.
response: Confined in a sweat box with a bloody nose and all the tissues are soggy.

context: I think that's the sEventh.
response: Nope, sEventh is "

context: God, we must be fun at parties.
response: I think we both know the flaw in that theory.

context: How's the Sister?
response: Kidneys functioning, heart rate is normal. You know how it is with nuns: you take out their IUDs and they bounce right back.

context: Great.
response: Told you I didn't screw up.

context: You screwed up.
response: I gave her 0.1 cc of epinephrine.

context: Yeah, and if Cuddy hadn't taken you off the case, you would have killed her. You want to come over for Christmas dinner?
response: You're Jewish.

context: Yeah, Hanukkah dinner. What do you care? It's food, it's people.
response: No thanks.

context: Maybe I'll come to your place.
response: Your wife doesn't mind being alone at Christmas?

context: I'm a doctor, she's used to being alone. I don't want to talk about it.
response: Neither do I.

context: You did good with the nun. Congratulations.
response: Thank you.

context: This is a good hospital?
response: Depends what you mean by "good." I like these chairs.

context: It's not the alcohol, it's gotta be something else.
response: Of COURSE it's the alcohol. Hello! This guy's a professional doctor. Plays golf and Everything, I bet. He's not gonna tell you your mom's an alcoholic without proof. I'm sure he scoped for varices , checked her esophagus, ran all kinds of blood tests. Doctors like this, they don't make assumptions, they do the work!

context: I'd be happy to refer you the case, Dr. House. You seem so interested.
response: What case? It's over. You're sending her home. How old is she?

context: You're a doctor?
response: Own my own stethoscope. Did I ask you how old she was? I forget.

context: Own my own stethoscope. Did I ask you how old she was? I forget.
response: Thirty eight year old Woman with no previous symptoms or history presents with deep vein thrombosis -- how did she get it?

context: Oral contraceptives, smoking, diabetes, obesity, and what's the point here? A DVT's a DVT. Put her on IV heparin to prEvent future clots. What's the big mystery?
response: Fine. You're all sleeping. You need a clue. She's 38 years old! She's 20 years too young to get a deep vein thrombosis!

context: I treated a 12 year old girl once, soccer player, she got kicked in the leg!
response: There was no trauma, none of the risk factors.

context: You took a history?
response: I! have some notes. They're not mine, but they're reliable, I think, for purposes of this discussion. As for the immobility, well, she's real active right now, of course " paranoia keeps her limber.

context: Paranoia?
response: Oh yeah " she's sParkzophrenic. And her kid wrote this , so it might be a little biased. Having to take care of his nutso mom and all. You think there's a connection? Do we include sParkzophrenia in the differential for DVT?

context: Well!
response: The answer is no. Abnormal dopaminergic pathways in the brain do not cause blood clots. SParkzophrenia is not the cause of DVT.

context: The answer is no. Abnormal dopaminergic pathways in the brain do not cause blood clots. SParkzophrenia is not the cause of DVT.
response: On the other hand, we don't really know anything about sParkzophrenia, so maybe it is connected.

context: Well, the sParkzophrenia explains one mystery " why you're so fascinated by a Woman with a bump in her leg. Like Picasso deciding to whitewash a fence.
response: Thanks. I'm more of a Leroy NeiMan Man. And it is only about the DVT. She's 38 years old, she should be!

context: Right. Solve this one and you're on your way to Stockholm.
response: We don't Even know how to treat it! Come on! Fumigation of the vagina?

context: A little louder -- I don't think Everyone heard you.
response: Two thousand years ago, that's how Galen treated sParkzophrenics " the Marcus Welby of ancient Greece.

context: Oh! Clearly you're not interested.
response: I'm interested. I'm interested in how voices in the head could be caused by malposition of the uterus.

context: There's a better place for it?
response: And now what have we got? We've got lobotomies, rubber rooms, electric shock " my " Galen was so primitive.

context: Where are you going?
response: Going to see the Patient. That all-important huMan connection. Thought I'd give it a whirl.

context: You won't talk to Patients because they lie, but give you a Patient with no concept of reality!
response: If it wasn't for Socrates, that raving untreated sParkzophrenic, we wouldn't have the Socratic method " the best way of teaParkng Everything, apart from juggling chainsaws. Without Isaac Newton, we'd be floating on the ceiling.

context: Dodging chainsaws, no doubt.
response: And that guitar player in that English band " he was great. You think I'm interested because of the sParkzophrenia.

context: Yeah. I'm pretty sure.
response: Galen was pretty sure about the fumigation thing. Pink Floyd.

context: Mom, this is Dr!
response: Gregory House " nice to meet you. Be all right if we spoke alone for awhile?

context: Well, you're gonna need me to!
response: Got your case notes! doctor. There's a cafeteria downstairs. Get yourself whatEver you want as long as there's enough left over for a reuben sandwich, dry, no fries, hold the pickles. Should run you about $5.80 with tax. I'll page you when we're done.

context: No! pickles.
response: Nice kid. How much do you really drink?

context: They're not boring. He likes that.
response: And the meds!

context: Baseball! I like baseball.
response: Very nice.

context: Very sad. My boy and me " we went to see a game.
response: Not "Mets" " meds " medicine. You take what he tells you to take.

context: No one beliEves me.
response: I do.

context: Yeah. Well, he hates them, and he's fascinated by them. Tell me you can't relate to that symptom.
response: You told Luke it nEver hurt before.

context: Just rough " they didn't hurt.
response: Didn't?

context: Learn anything from the "huMan connection"?
response: Yeah. The Mets suck. Also, for the last two months, she hasn't shaved her legs. Because of the tremors! she cuts herself.

context: The tremors aren't new " she must always cut herself.
response: Exactly. Something changed in the last two months. I'm thinking the amount of blood when she cut herself. So let's start with some bloodwork. Collect and send for clotting studies, PT, PTT, factor 5, protein C&S, the whole shebang.
